repnme.cdata!: Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Forestry
            Project for the Ivory Coast was unsatisfactory. The project
            did not achieve many of its objectives, institutional
            development was negligible, sustainability is unlikely, and
            the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            unsatisfactory. Lessons to be drawn from this project are
            similar to those derived from many of the other Bank's
            integrated rural development projects. The establishment of
            region-specific, specialized project institutions does not
            compensate, in the long run, for a weak national program of
            agricultural support services; the aim should be to provide
            training and technical assistance that will enable the
            Government to strengthen these services. The project also
            demonstrated that it is difficult for crop-based rural
            development agencies to satisfactorily assume the
            responsibility for promoting food crops. In tackling the
            deficit of the tree crop development agencies, it will be
            necessary for food crop promotion to be financed under
            Government's general program of research and extension,
            rather than charged to coffee-cocoa producers.

docna.cdata!: Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa Development Project

display_title.display_title:
Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa
            Development Project

docna.cdata!:
Togo - Third Coffee And Cocoa Development
            Project : Credit 1745 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Togo - Third Coffee And Cocoa
            Development Project : Credit 1745 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

repnme.cdata!: Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Cocoa and Coffee Project will
            aim to increase coffee and cocoa production through
            improving the productivity of investments under the first
            and second cocoa-coffee development projects and by
            plantings in new areas. It will be implemented over five
            years and will include: (a) provision of inputs and
            technical advice to farmers for the planting of 7,500 ha of
            coffee and 2,000 ha of cocoa, maintenance of existing 16,600
            ha of coffee planted under the first two projects, and
            development of some 22,000 ha of foodcrops. The Third Cocoa
            and Coffee Project will also finance the (b) implementation
            of annual plant protection programs against pest attacks on
            existing cocoa trees (mirid and blackpod); (c) applied
            research in coffee, cocoa and foodcrops; as well as (d)
            construction (250 km) and maintenance of feeder roads. In
            addition, the project will support (e) establishment of
            about 250 farmers' groups for marketing, input
            distribution and saving purposes; (f) support to the
            National Cocoa and Coffee Development Company (SRCC),
            including 14 man-years of technical assistance and 12
            man-months of short-term consultants' services; and (g)
            studies of land tenure problems in the project area and a
            future strategy for cocoa-coffee development in Togo.

docna.cdata!: Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa Development Project

repnme.cdata!: Togo - Third Coffee and Cocoa Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Cocoa and Coffee Project will
            aim to increase coffee and cocoa production through
            improving the productivity of investments under the first
            and second cocoa-coffee development projects and by
            plantings in new areas.  It will be implemented over five
            years and will include:  (a) provision of inputs and
            technical advice to farmers for the planting of 7,500 ha of
            coffee and 2,000 ha of cocoa, maintenance of existing 16,600
            ha of coffee planted under the first two projects, and
            development of some 22,000 ha of foodcrops.  The Third Cocoa
            and Coffee Project will also finance the (b) implementation
            of annual plant protection programs against pest attacks on
            existing cocoa trees (mirid and blackpod); (c) applied
            research in coffee, cocoa and foodcrops; as well as (d)
            construction (250 km) and maintenance of feeder roads.  In
            addition, the project will support (e) establishment of
            about 250 farmers' groups for marketing, input
            distribution and saving purposes; (f) support to the
            National Cocoa and Coffee Development Company (SRCC),
            including 14 man-years of technical assistance and 12
            man-months of short-term consultants' services; and (g)
            studies of land tenure problems in the project area and a
            future strategy for cocoa-coffee development in Togo.
